channel.title: NYT > Books > Book Review
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Review: “Democratic Justice,” by Brad Snyder
item.description: “Democratic Justice,” Brad Snyder’s comprehensive biography of Felix Frankfurter, aims to reassess the complicated legacy of the judge and political adviser.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Rosen
item.category: Democratic Justice: Felix Frankfurter, the Supreme Court, and the Making of the Liberal Establishment (Book)

item.title: Review: ‘The Stolen Year,’ by Anya Kamenetz
item.description: “The Stolen Year,” by Anya Kamenetz, is an account of Covid’s devastating effects on American youth.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Menkedick
item.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
item.media:description: In “The Stolen Year,” Anya Kamenetz details the harm of school closures, among many other problems, during the pandemic.

item.title: Review: “Babysitter,” by Joyce Carol Oates
item.description: Her latest novel uses horror and a privileged white protagonist as vehicles for social critique.
item.dc:creator: Oyinkan Braithwaite

item.title: New Romance Novels to Read
item.description: Lydia San Andres sets “Compromised Into a Scandalous Marriage” in the Edwardian-era Caribbean.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Waite
item.category: High Times in the Low Parliament (Book)

item.title: Review: ‘Afterlives,’ by Abdulrazak Gurnah
item.description: “Afterlives,” the new novel from the Nobel laureate Abdulrazak Gurnah, is set in colonial-era German East Africa.
item.dc:creator: Imbolo Mbue

item.title: In Julian Barnes’s New Novel, a Teacher’s Pet Becomes Obsessed
item.description: “Elizabeth Finch” is about an adult student who becomes the inheritor of a beloved teacher’s intellectual work.
item.dc:creator: Molly Young

item.title: Read Your Way Through Reykjavík
item.description: With a reputation for having more authors per capita than any other country, Iceland is a destination for readers. Olaf Olafsson, whose most recent book is “Touch,” leads a literary stroll through its capital.
item.dc:creator: Olaf Olafsson

item.title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
item.description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
item.category: Inventor of the Future: The Visionary Life of Buckminster Fuller (Book)

item.title: Robert Caro on ‘Working’
item.description: The acclaimed biographer of Lyndon B. Johnson and Robert Moses talks about his methods.

item.title: Review: Jared Kushner’s ‘Breaking History’ Is a Soulless and Very Selective Memoir
item.description: In this lengthy book, Kushner recounts the time he spent in the White House during his father-in-law’s term.
item.dc:creator: Dwight Garner
item.category: Breaking History: A White House Memoir (Book)

item.title: Review: ‘All the Living and the Dead,’ by Hayley Campbell
item.description: In her new book, “All the Living and the Dead,” Hayley Campbell explores the invisible labor that powers the death industry.
item.dc:creator: Albert Samaha

item.title: Review: ‘Complicit,’ by Winnie M Li
item.description: In her new novel, “Complicit,” Winnie M Li explores the collateral damage of assault on both victims and witnesses.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan
item.media:description: Li is a former film producer and the founder of Clear Lines, the U.K’.s first-ever festival addressing sexual assault through arts and discussion. She is a rape survivor.

item.title: Review: ‘Forever Truffle,’ by Fanny Britt and Isabelle Arsenault
item.description: Fanny Britt and Isabelle Arsenault’s sequel to their graphic novel “Louis Undercover” turns the music up a notch.
item.dc:creator: Vera Brosgol

item.title: Review: “Africa Is Not a Country," by Dipo Faloyin
item.description: Dipo Faloyin is tired of Western stereotypes.
item.dc:creator: Michela Wrong
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times, Nyancho Nwanri/Reuters, Khadija Farah for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clockwise from left: A man loads food supplies at a dock on the Congo River, in Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo, on April 21, 2021; Downtown Nairobi, Kenya, in 2020; Nigeria’s commercial capital of Lagos, in February 2019.

item.title: Book Review: “The Unfolding,” by A.M. Homes
item.description: “The Unfolding” takes readers inside the homes and meeting rooms of a dyed-in-the-wool conservative with big plans for change.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Haigh

item.title: Review: “A Continent Erupts,” by Ronald H. Spector
item.description: In “A Continent Erupts,” Ronald H. Spector chronicles the violent, internecine conflicts that overwhelmed Asia in the decade after World War II.
item.dc:creator: Sheila Miyoshi Jager
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Korean soldiers retreating after a Chinese offensive in May 1951.

item.title: Book Review: “Partisans,” by Nicole Hemmer
item.description: A new book by the historian Nicole Hemmer charts the demise of Reagan-style optimism and the birth of a rage-and-fear-based politics on the right.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Szalai
item.category: Partisans: The Conservative Revolutionaries Who Remade American Politics in the 1990s (Book)

item.title: Review: “The Life of Crime,” by Martin Edwards
item.description: In “The Life of Crime,” Martin Edwards takes on the colorful history of the detective novel, and its enduring fascination.
item.dc:creator: Jane Pek
item.category: The Life of Crime: Detecting the History of Mysteries and Their Creators (Book)
item.media:description: The American comedian Buster Keaton (1895-1966), armed with only a magnifying glass and a copy of “How To Be A Detective,” hopes to become a great detective in the film “Sherlock Junior.”

item.title: Book Review: ‘The House of Fortune’ by Jessie Burton
item.description: In “The House of Fortune,” Jessie Burton’s characters are 18 years older and much has changed.
item.dc:creator: Louis Bayard

item.title: Review: Essays by Gary Indiana, David Collard and Charles Baxter
item.description: Cultural criticism from Gary Indiana, David Collard and Charles Baxter.
item.dc:creator: Lori Soderlind
item.category: Multiple Joyce: 100 Short Essays About James Joyce's Cultural Legacy (Book)
Wonderlands: Essays on the Life of Literature (Book)

item.title: New Historical Fiction to Read
item.description: In three journeys to the past, characters find themselves on quests that have nothing to do with the calendar or geography.
item.dc:creator: Alida Becker

item.title: Review: ‘Wild Things Are Happening,’ by Jonathan Weinberg
item.description: A new book collects six decades’ worth of the artist’s work.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Christensen
item.category: Wild Things Are Happening: The Art of Maurice Sendak (Book)
item.media:description: The watercolor figures in “Where the Wild Things Are” paved the way for more complex feelings and ideas in children’s literature.

item.title: Review: ‘A Visible Man: A Memoir,’ by Edward Enninful
item.description: The British Vogue editor wants to make the media — and the world — a more welcoming place.
item.dc:creator: Tariro Mzezewa

item.title: Review: ‘Didn’t Nobody Give a Shit What Happened to Carlotta,’ by James Hannaham
item.description: James Hannaham’s new novel imagines a convict’s fateful re-entry into a much-changed Brooklyn.
item.dc:creator: John Irving

item.title: Review: “American Rascal: How Jay Gould Built Wall Street’s Biggest Fortune,” by Greg Steinmetz
item.description: For better or worse, Jay Gould revolutionized the world of finance in the 19th century. In “American Rascal,” Greg Steinmetz tells his story.
item.dc:creator: T.J. Stiles
item.category: American Rascal: How Jay Gould Built Wall Street's Biggest Fortune (Book)
item.media:description: Jay Gould was said to hold power over judges, as a cartoonist of the time noted.

item.title: John Lithgow on an Actor’s Education
item.description: The Emmy Award-winning star of TV, stage and movies discusses his memoir, “Drama.” And the British writer Maggie O’Farrell talks about her novel “Hamnet.”
item.media:credit: Photo illustration: The New York Times; Photos: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times; David Levenson/Getty Images

item.title: James Hannaham By the Book Interview
item.description: “Wasn’t it Louis Armstrong who said there are only two types of music — good and bad?” says the author and visual artist, whose new novel is “Didn’t Nobody Give a Shit What Happened to Carlotta.” “I feel the same about books. I like good.”

item.title: Review: “The Arc of a Covenant,” by Walter Russell Mead
item.description: In “The Arc of a Covenant,” Walter Russell Mead makes the case that U.S. support for the Jewish state has benefited America more than critics allow.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tepperman

item.title: Review: “The Secret Battle of Evan Pao,” by Wendy Wan-Long Shang
item.description: In “The Secret Battle of Evan Pao,” a Chinese American boy and his family feel as if they’re refighting the U.S. Civil War.
item.dc:creator: Shing Yin Khor

item.title: Review: “The Tryout” by Christina Soontornvat
item.description: The Thai American heroine of Christina Soontornvat’s graphic novel wrestles with anti-Asian racism while auditioning for the cheerleading squad.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Mathieu

item.title: Coding and Creative Writing Have More in Common Than You Think
item.description: While other future novelists were discussing iambic pentameter and leitmotifs, Gina Chen immersed herself in computer science.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan
